sen.j: アメノヒボコ（天之日矛、天日槍）は、『古事記』、『日本書紀』の日本神話に登場する神。
sen.e: Amenohiboko is a deity in Japanese mythology, who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
Amenohiboko is a deity in Japanese mythology, who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
Amenohiboko is a deity in Japanese mythology, who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 元は新羅の王子だった。
sen.e: He was a prince of Silla (an ancient Korean kingdom).
He was a prince of Silla (an ancient Korean kingdom).
He was a prince of Silla (an ancient Korean kingdom).

sen.j: アメノヒボコの曾孫が、菓子の神とされるタヂマモリ（多遅摩毛理、田道間守）である。
sen.e: His great-grandson was Tajimamori, a deity of sweets.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: His great-grandson was Tajimamori, a deity of sweets.
His great-grandson was Tajimamori, a deity of sweets.

sen.j: 次の代の多遅摩比多詞の娘が息長帯比売命（神功皇后）の母、葛城高額比売命である。
sen.e: Tajimamori's daughter was Katsuraginotakanukahime no mikoto, the mother of Okinagatarashihime no mikoto (Empress Jingu).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Tajimamori's daughter was Katsuraginotakanukahime no mikoto, the mother of Okinagatarashihime no mikoto (Empress Jingu).
Tajimamori's daughter was Katsuraginotakanukahime no mikoto, the mother of Okinagatarashihime no mikoto (Empress Jingu).

sen.j: なお、アメノヒボコは新羅の王家、新羅建国神話、瓠公との関連の可能性があるとする説もある。
sen.e: Additionally, some say that Amenohiboko might have been connected to Koko, a Japanese retainer believed to have served Korean kings and help them found Silla.
Additionally, some say that Amenohiboko might have been connected to Koko, a Japanese retainer believed to have served Korean kings and help them found Silla.
Additionally, some say that Amenohiboko might have been connected to Koko, a Japanese retainer believed to have served Korean kings and help them found Silla.

sen.j: いずれにせよ、「天」が名前につき、皇室の祖先に深く関係する神（例：高天原の神）並みの表記である。
sen.e: In any event, his name, which contains the Chinese character of "天" (the heaven), suggests that he may have been closely connected to the ancestors of the imperial family (just like deities in Takamanohara (the heavens)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In any event, his name, which contains the Chinese character of "天" (heaven), suggests that he may have been closely connected to the ancestors of the imperial family (just like deities in Takamanohara (heaven).

In any event, his name, which contains the Chinese character of '天' (heaven), suggests that he may have been closely connected to the ancestors of the imperial family (just like deities in Takamanohara (heaven)).
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'に文末に）補足

sen.j: 他国の王子の名としては「天」の漢字がついた名は、他に類例がない。
sen.e: There was no other prince from foreign countries whose name contained the Chinese character of "天".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: There was no other prince from foreign countries whose name contained the Chinese character of "天".
There was no other prince from foreign countries whose name contained the Chinese character of '天.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にピリオドを'内に移動

sen.j: 『古事記』では、以下のように伝える。
sen.e: Kojiki describes Amenohiboko as follows;
Kojiki describes Amenohiboko as follows;
Kojiki describes Amenohiboko as follows;

sen.j: 昔、新羅のアグヌマ（阿具奴摩、阿具沼）という沼で女が昼寝をしていた。
sen.e: A long time ago, in Silla, a woman was taking a nap near a pond called "Agunuma".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: A long time ago, in Silla, a woman was taking a nap near a pond called "Agunuma."
A long time ago, in Silla, a woman was taking a nap near a pond called "Agunuma."

sen.j: その陰部に日の光が虹のようになって当たった。
sen.e: Then, a ray of sunlight fell on her private parts like a rainbow.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Then, a ray of sunlight fell on her private parts like a rainbow.
Then, a ray of sunlight fell on her private parts like a rainbow.

sen.j: すると女はたちまち娠んで、赤い玉を産んだ。
sen.e: Immediately, she became pregnant and gave birth to a red jewel.
Immediately, she became pregnant and gave birth to a red jewel.
Immediately, she became pregnant and gave birth to a red jewel.

sen.j: その様子を見ていた男は乞い願ってその玉を貰い受け、肌身離さず持ち歩いていた。
sen.e: A man, who was watching this, pleaded her to give him the jewel, received it from her, and carried it with him all the time.
A man, who was watching this, pleaded with her to give him the jewel, received it from her, and carried it with him all the time.
A man, who was watching this, pleaded with her to give him the jewel, received it from her, and carried it with him all the time.

sen.j: ある日、男が牛で食べ物を山に運んでいる途中、アメノヒボコと出会った。
sen.e: One day, he met Amenohiboko when carrying food to a mountain using a cow.
One day, he met Amenohiboko when carrying food to a mountain using a ox.
One day, he met Amenohiboko when carrying food to a mountain using a ox.

sen.j: ヒボコは、男が牛を殺して食べるつもりだと勘違いして捕えて牢獄に入れようとした。
sen.e: Hiboko, who assumed that the man was going to kill and eat the cow, arrested him to put him in jail.
Hiboko, who assumed that the man was going to kill and eat the ox, arrested him to put him in jail.
Hiboko, who assumed that the man was going to kill and eat the ox, arrested him to put him in jail.

sen.j: 男が釈明をしてもヒボコは許さなかった。
sen.e: He contended, but Hiboko would not listen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: The man went along with the arrest, but Hiboko would not listen.
The man tried to explain however Hiboko would not forgive him.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 男はいつも持ち歩いていた赤い玉を差し出した。
sen.e: So, he showed him the red jewel that he had been carrying all the time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: So, he showed him the red jewel that he had been carrying all the time.
So, he showed him the red jewel that he had been carrying all the time.

sen.j: ようやく許してもらえた。
sen.e: In exchange for the jewel, he was finally pardoned.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In exchange for the jewel, he was finally pardoned.
In exchange for the jewel, he was finally pardoned.

sen.j: ヒボコがその玉を持ち帰って床に置くと、玉は美しい娘になった。
sen.e: When he brought the jewel back home and put it on a floor, it turned into a beautiful lady.
When he brought the jewel back home and put it on the floor, it turned into a beautiful lady.
When he brought the jewel back home and put it on the floor, it turned into a beautiful lady.

sen.j: ヒボコは娘を正妻とし、娘は毎日美味しい料理を出していた。
sen.e: He made her his lawful wife, and she served delicious dishes for him every day.
He made her his lawful wife, and she served delicious dishes for him every day.
He made her his lawful wife, and she served delicious dishes for him every day.

sen.j: しかし、ある日奢り高ぶったヒボコが妻を罵った。
sen.e: One day, however, Hiboko became arrogant and bitterly badmouthed her.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: One day, however, Hiboko became arrogant and bitterly badmouthed her.
One day, however, Hiboko became arrogant and bitterly badmouthed her.

sen.j: 親の国に帰ると言って逃げた。
sen.e: Frustrated, his wife ran away from him, saying that she would go back to her parents' country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Frustrated, his wife ran away from him, saying that she would go back to her parents' country.
Frustrated, his wife ran away from him, saying that she would go back to her parents' country.

sen.j: 小舟に乗って難波の津の比売碁曾神社（大阪市東成区 現在の主祭神は大国主の娘の下照比売命（シタテルヒメ））に着いた。
sen.e: She arrived at Himegoso-jinja Shrine (Higashinari Ward, Osaka City, now Shitateruhime, a daughter of Okuninushi, is enshrined) near Naniwa tsu (today's Osaka Port) by boat.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: She arrived at Himegoso-jinja Shrine (Higashinari Ward, Osaka City, now Shitateruhime, a daughter of Okuninushi, is enshrined) near Naniwa tsu (today's Osaka Port) by boat.
She arrived at Himegoso-jinja Shrine (Higashinari Ward, Osaka City, now Shitateruhime, a daughter of Okuninushi, is enshrined) near Naniwa tsu (today's Osaka Port) by boat.

sen.j: ヒボコは反省して、妻を追って日本へ来た。
sen.e: Hiboko, who was repentant, came all the way to Japan, chasing his wife.
Hiboko, who was repentant, came all the way to Japan, chasing his wife.
Hiboko, who was repentant, came all the way to Japan, chasing his wife.

sen.j: この妻の名は阿加流比売神（アカルヒメ）である。
sen.e: His wife's name was Akaru hime.
His wife's name was Akaru hime.
His wife's name was Akaru hime.

sen.j: しかし、難波の海峡を支配する神が遮って妻の元へ行くことができなかった。
sen.e: But he could not meet her in the end as the deity that ruled the Naniwa straits was in the way.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: But he could not meet her in the end because the deity that ruled the Naniwa straits was in the way.
But he could not meet her in the end because the deity that ruled the Naniwa straits was in the way.

sen.j: ヒコボは、但馬国に上陸し、そこで現地の娘・前津見と結婚したとしている。
sen.e: He came ashore on a beach in Tajima Province, and eventually, got married to a local girl, Maetsumi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: He came ashore on a beach in Tajima Province, and eventually, got married to a local girl, Maetsumi.
He came ashore on a beach in Tajima Province, and eventually, got married to a local girl, Maetsumi.

sen.j: 垂仁天皇3年春3月に新羅王の子・アメノヒボコが渡来した。
sen.e: In spring (March) of the third year of Emperor Suinin's reign, Amenohiboko, a prince of Silla came to Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In spring (March) of the third year of Emperor Suinin's reign, Amenohiboko, a prince from Silla came to Japan.
In spring (March) of the third year of Emperor Suinin's reign, Amenohiboko, a prince from Silla came to Japan.

sen.j: 神宝、羽太の玉、足高の玉、赤石、刀、矛、鏡、熊の神籬の８種を持参した。
sen.e: He brought with him eight kinds of sacred treasures: Hafuto-no-tama jewels, Ashitaka-no-tama jewels, red stones, swords, pikes, mirrors, and Kuma no himorogi (a temporarily erected sacred space or an altar used as a locus of worship).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理「熊の神籬」については、なぜ、熊の」という表現がつくのか、専門家の間でもわかっていないそうです。
sen.e: He brought with him eight kinds of sacred treasures: Hafuto-no-tama jewels, Ashitaka-no-tama jewels, red stones, swords, pikes, mirrors, and Kuma no himorogi (a temporarily erected sacred space or an altar used as a locus of worship).

He brought with him eight kinds of sacred treasures: Hafuto-no-tama jewels, Ashitaka-no-tama jewels, red stones, swords, pikes, mirrors, and Kuma no himorogi (a temporarily erected sacred space or an altar used as a locus of worship).

sen.j: また、播磨国、近江国、若狭国を経て但馬国の出石に至り、そこに定住して現地の娘・麻多烏（またお）と結婚したとしている。
sen.e: He finally reached Deishi in Tajima Province after travelling though Harima, Omi, and Wakasa Provinces, and settled there, making a local girl, Matao, his wife.
He finally reached Deishi in Tajima Province after travelling though Harima, Omi, and Wakasa Provinces, and settled there, making a local girl, Matao, his wife.
He finally reached Deishi in Tajima Province after travelling though Harima, Omi, and Wakasa Provinces, and settled there, making a local girl, Matao, his wife.

sen.j: これらの神宝は太陽神を祀る呪具であり、朝鮮からの渡来民が使っていた太陽神を祀る祭具と考えられる。
sen.e: These treasures might have been the tools of Korean settlers for worshipping the sun god.
These treasures might have been the tools of Korean settlers for worshipping the sun god.
These treasures might have been the tools of Korean settlers for worshipping the sun god.

sen.j: 「ヒボコ」という名前自体が太陽神を祀る祭儀で使われる矛を表している。
sen.e: His name, "Hiboko", itself means a pike, which was used in rituals to worship the sun god.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: His name, "Hiboko," itself means a pike, which was used in rituals to worship the sun god.
His name, 'Hiboko,' itself means a pike, which was used in rituals to worship the sun god.

sen.j: 太陽神の依り代でもある。
sen.e: The pike was also considered to be Yorishiro (an object a divine spirit reside).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: The pike was also considered to be Yorishiro (an object a divine spirit resides in).
The pike was also considered to be Yorishiro (an object a divine spirit resides in).

sen.j: またここで登場する国は渡来系の人々の影響の強い土地である。
sen.e: The province mentioned here came under strong influence of Korean settlers.
The province mentioned here came under strong influence from Korean settlers.
The province mentioned here came under strong influence from Korean settlers.

sen.j: 定住した但馬国では国土開発の祖神とされ、現在でも厚く信仰されている。
sen.e: In Tajima Province where Hiboko settled, he has been believed to be the deity of land development and still deeply worshipped by people.
In Tajima Province where Hiboko settled, he has been believed to be the deity of land development and still deeply worshipped by people.
In Tajima Province where Hiboko settled, he has been believed to be the deity of land development and still deeply worshipped by people.

sen.j: これらのことから、アメノヒボコは出石に住んでいた新羅系の渡来人が信仰していた神と考えられる。
sen.e: This helps us conclude that Amehiboko was a deity worshipped by Korean settlers in Deishi.
This helps us conclude that Amehiboko was a deity worshipped by Korean settlers in Deishi.
This helps us conclude that Amenohiboko was a deity worshipped by Korean settlers in Deishi.

sen.j: 『古事記』によれば珠が2つ、浪振比礼（ひれ）、浪切比礼、風振比礼、風切比礼、奥津鏡、辺津鏡の八種である。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki", there were eight kinds of treasures: two types of jewels, Namifuru-no-hire (shawl to calm the wave), Namikiru-no-hire (shawl to cut the wave), Kazefuru-no-hire (shawl to calm the wind), Kazekiru-no-hire (shawl to cut the wind), Okitsu-kagami mirror, and Hetsu-kagami mirror.

According to "Kojiki," there were eight kinds of treasures: two types of jewels, Namifuru-no-hire (shawl to calm the wave), Namikiru-no-hire (shawl to cut the wave), Kazefuru-no-hire (shawl to calm the wind), Kazekiru-no-hire (shawl to cut the wind), Okitsu-kagami mirror, and Hetsu-kagami mirror.

According to "Kojiki," there were eight kinds of treasures: two types of jewels, Namifuru no hire (shawl to calm the wave), Namikiru no hire (shawl to cut the wave), Kazefuru no hire (shawl to calm the wind), Kazekiru no hire (shawl to cut the wind), Okitsu-kagami mirror, and Hetsu-kagami mirror.

sen.j: これらは現在、兵庫県豊岡市出石町の出石神社にアメノヒボコとともに祀られている。
sen.e: These treasures are enshrined as deities in Izushi-jinja Shrine (Izushi-cho, Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture), together with Amehiboko.
sen.cmt: 「これらの神宝が祭られている」と記されていますが、これらを八座の神として祀っているということです。
sen.e: These treasures are enshrined as deities in Izushi-jinja Shrine (Izushi-cho, Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture), together with Amehiboko.
These treasures are enshrined as deities in Izushi-jinja Shrine (Izushi-cho, Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture), together with Amenohiboko.

sen.j: いずれも海上の波風を鎮める呪具であった。
sen.e: All of these were tools used to pray for the wind and wave in the ocean to die down.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: All of these were tools used to pray for the wind and waves in the ocean to die down.
All of these were tools used to pray for the wind and waves in the ocean to die down.

sen.j: 海人族が信仰していた海の神の信仰とアメノヒボコの信仰が結びついたものと考えられる。
sen.e: This represents a combined form of faith in the sea god by people who lived and worked on the seas and worship for Amehiboko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: This represents a combined form of faith in the sea god by people who lived and worked on the seas and worship for Amehiboko.
This represents a combined form of faith in the sea god by people who lived and worked on the seas and worship for Amenohiboko.

tit.e: Harima no kuni-fudoki (a description of the climate and culture of Harima Province)
Harima no kuni-fudoki (a description of the climate and culture of Harima Province)
Harima no kuni-fudoki (a description of the climate and culture of Harima Province)

sen.j: 『播磨国風土記』では神代の渡来神・天日槍命として登場している。
sen.e: In Harima no kuni-fudoki, Amenohiboko is referred to as Amenohiboko-no-mikoto and described as a deity who came from a foreign country and settled in Japan in the age of the gods.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In Harima no kuni-fudoki, Amenohiboko is referred to as Amenohiboko-no-mikoto and described as a deity who came from a foreign country and settled in Japan in the age of the gods.
In Harima no kuni-fudoki, Amenohiboko is referred to as Amenohiboko no mikoto and described as a deity who came from a foreign country and settled in Japan in the age of the gods.

sen.j: 天日槍命は、葦原志挙乎命（葦原志許乎命）・伊和神社と土地を奪い合った神として描かれている。
sen.e: He contended for land with Ashiharashikoo-no-mikoto (Ashiharashikoo-no-mikoto), who are enshrined in Iwa-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: He went along with the land with Ashiharashikoo-no-mikoto (Ashiharashikoo-no-mikoto), who are enshrined in Iwa-jinja Shrine.
He fought over the land with Ashiharashikoo no mikoto (葦原志挙乎命) (Ashiharashikoo no mikoto (葦原志許乎命)), who are enshrined in Iwa-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 「奪い合った」の意味が出るように訳し直しました。。ハイフン削除漢字を補足NR: I cannot imagine what " went along with the land" is supposed to mean here. As the Japanese says "奪い合う" I think "fought over" would be more appropriate.

sen.j: （どちらも大国主と同一視される。）
sen.e: (Both of them were regarded as identical to Okuninushi (the chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan).)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: (Both of them were regarded as identical to Okuninushi (the chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan).)
(Both of them were regarded as identical to Okuninushi (the chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan).)

sen.j: 記紀とは年代や争いがあったかどうかなどが異なる。
sen.e: The descriptions of ages and whether there was contention or not in the fudoki are not necessarily consistent with those of "Kojiki" or "Nihonshoki".
The descriptions of ages and whether there was contention or not in the fudoki are not necessarily consistent with those of "Kojiki" or "Nihonshoki".
The descriptions of ages and whether there was contention or not in the fudoki are not necessarily consistent with those of Kojiki or Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 揖保郡、宍粟郡、神崎郡 (兵庫県)の地名説話として争いが描かれている。
sen.e: In this fudoki, contention is described in the local tales of Ibo, Shiso, and Kanzaki Counties.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In this fudoki, contention is described in the local tales of Ibo, Shiso, and Kanzaki Counties.
In this fudoki, contention is described in the local tales of Ibo, Shiso, and Kanzaki Counties.

sen.j: 争いの結末は双方が三本の黒葛を投げる占いの結果だった。
sen.e: They put an end to the contention by leaving the decision to the result obtained by throwing three black ivy vines.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: They put an end to the contention by leaving the decision to the result obtained by throwing three black ivy vines.
They put an end to the contention by leaving the decision to the result obtained by throwing three black ivy vines.

sen.j: 占いの結果、葦原志挙乎命の葛は播磨に一本・但馬に二本、天日槍命の葛は全て但馬に落ちた。
sen.e: The result was that one of the three vines thrown by Ashiharashikoo-no-mikoto fell in Harima and the rest fell in Tajima, whereas all of the three vines thrown by Amenohiboko-no-mikoto dropped in Tajima.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: The result was that one of the three vines thrown by Ashiharashikoo-no-mikoto fell in Harima and the rest fell in Tajima, whereas all of the three vines thrown by Amenohiboko-no-mikoto dropped in Tajima.

The result was that one of the three vines thrown by Ashiharashikoo no mikoto fell in Harima and the rest fell in Tajima, whereas all of the three vines thrown by Amenohiboko no mikoto dropped in Tajima.

sen.j: 天日槍命が但馬出石に退くことになったとしている。
sen.e: This forced Amenohiboko to retreat to Deishi, Tajima.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: This forced Amenohiboko to retreat to Deishi, Tajima.
This forced Amenohiboko to retreat to Deishi, Tajima.

sen.j: 名前に「ホコ」があるように天日槍命には製鉄との関連があった。
sen.e: As his name, "boko" (= "hiko", meaning a pike), suggests, Amenohiboko-no-mikoto was related to iron-making.
As his name, "boko" (= "hiko", meaning a pike), suggests, Amenohiboko-no-mikoto was related to iron-making.
As his name, 'boko' (= 'hiko,' meaning a pike), suggests, Amenohiboko-no-mikoto was related to iron-making.

sen.j: これは土着勢力と渡来系の製鉄集団の鉄を巡る争いであったと考えられている。
sen.e: This may imply that there was contention for iron between indigenous and foreign people.
This may imply that there was contention for iron between indigenous and foreign people.
This may imply that there was contention for iron between indigenous and foreign people.

tit.j: ツヌガアラシト（都怒我阿羅斯等）

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では、アメノヒボコの渡来前に伽耶国王の子の都怒我阿羅斯等が渡来したという。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," Tsunugaarashito, a prince of Kaya (an ancient Korean kingdom) came to Japan before Amenohiboko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," Tsunugaarashito, a prince of Kaya (an ancient Korean kingdom) came to Japan before Amenohiboko.
According to "Nihonshoki," Tsunugaarashito, a prince of Kaya (an ancient Korean kingdom) came to Japan before Amenohiboko.

sen.j: この説話の前半部分、アカルヒメが日本に渡りそれを追いかける部分の主人公である。
sen.e: In it, he is depicted as the hero of the tale mentioned here earlier, who came all the way to Japan to chase his wife, Akaruhime.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In it, he is depicted as the hero of the tale mentioned here earlier, who came all the way to Japan to chase his wife, Akaruhime.
In it, he is depicted as the hero of the tale mentioned here earlier, who came all the way to Japan to chase his wife, Akaruhime.

sen.j: 都怒我阿羅斯等は3年後に帰国したという。
sen.e: But he is said to have returned to his country after three years of stay in Japan.
But he is said to have returned to his country after three years in Japan.
But he is said to have returned to his country after three years in Japan.

sen.j: なお子孫は『新撰姓氏録』によれば左京諸藩に清水首・大市首、大和国諸藩に辟田首がいる。
sen.e: Additionally, according to "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), Shimizu-no-obito and Ochi-no-obito in Sakyo-shoban, and Hekita-no-obito in Yamato Province-shoban were his descendents.
sen.cmt: 「左京諸藩」「大和国諸藩」ですが、「諸藩」の解釈ですが、はっきりしません。一応、音のみは訳しましたが、註はあえてつけませんでした。
sen.e: Additionally, according to "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), Shimizu-no-obito and Ochi-no-obito in Sakyo-shoban, and Hekita-no-obito in Yamato Province-shoban were his descendents.

Additionally, according to "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), Shimizu no obito and Ochi no obito in Sakyo-shoban, and Hekita no obito in Yamato Province-shoban were his descendents.
